question: What's the difference between speed and velocity?
answer:
Speed is just how fast you're going (e.g. 30 mph or 20 m/s) with no regard to the direction.

Velocity however must also have the direction specified (e.g. 30 mph north, or 20 m/s, 060°).

question: What formula can you use to calculate average speed?
answer: Average speed = Distance moved ÷ Time taken

question: Define acceleration
answer:
How quickly the velocity is changing.
It can be a change in speed, change in direction, or both (but you only need to worry about change in speed for calculations).

question: How can you calculate acceleration?
answer: Acceleration = Change in velocity ÷ Time taken

question: On a distance-time graph, the gradient represents...
answer: Speed

question: A flat (horizontal) line on a distance-time graph shows...
answer: Where speed has stopped

question: Curves on a distance-time graph show...
answer: Acceleration or deceleration

question: How can you calculate speed from a distance-time graph?
answer: The gradient (i.e. vertical ÷ horizontal)

question: How is acceleration shown on a velocity-time graph?
answer: It's the gradient

question: Flat/horizontal lines on a velocity-time graph represent...
answer: Steady speed

question: On a velocity-time graph, a curve means...
answer: Changing acceleration

question: How can you calculate acceleration from a velocity-time graph?
answer: The gradient (i.e. vertical ÷ horizontal)

question: What is gravity?
answer:
The force of attraction between all masses.

• It makes things accelerate towards the ground on the surface of a planet
• It gives everything a weight
• It keeps planets, moons, etc. in their orbits.
• An orbit is a balance between the forward motion of the objet and the force of gracity pulling it inwards.

question: Describe the difference between weight and mass
answer:
Mass is the amount of 'stuff' in an object - for any given object, this will be the same anywhere in the Universe

Weight is caused by the pull of gravity. An object's weight will be different on different planets.

question: State the formula linking weight and mass
answer: Weight = mass × gravitational field strength

question: List at least five different types of force
answer:
• Gravity acting straight downwards
• Reaction force from a surface, usually acting straight upwards
• Electrostatic force between two charged objects (direction depends on the type of charges)
• Thrust when an engine or rocket speeds something up
• Drag / air resistance / friction slows an object down
• Lift due to an aeroplane wing
• Tension in a rope or cable

question: Friction occurs in three main ways. What are they?
answer:
• Friction between solid surfaces which are gripping (static friction)
• Friction between solid surfaces which are sliding past each other
• Resistance or 'drag' from fluids (liquids or gases - e.g. air).

question: How can you reduce friction between solid surfaces?
answer: Putting a lubricant like oil between the surfaces

question: How is friction/resistance/drag an issue in cars?
answer:
When cars move, there is air resistance which can slow things down.

Also, in fluids (like air), friction always increases as the speed increases

question: Describe an experiment to investiage the motion of a toy car on a ramp
answer:
• Mark a line on the ramp to make sure the car starts from the same points each time
• Measure the distances between light gates (place one at the start line, one at the end of the ramp/start of the runway, and another at the end of the runway). You need this to help with finding average speed.
• The light gate should be connected to a computer. So, when the car passes through each light gate, a beam of light is broken and a time is recorded.
• Repeat to find an average time it takes for the car to reach each light gate (more reliable results)
• Find the average speed using the distance between the gates and average time taken

question: Define terminal velocity
answer:
When an object falls freely, there is more force accelerating them than resistance slowing them down. As velocity increases, resistance builds up.

Eventually, the resistance force will be equal to the accelerating force and then it won't be able to accelerate any more. It will have reached its maximum velocity, or terminal velocity.

question: Explain why the hammer and feather, dropped simultaneously, hit the ground at the same time on the Moon?
answer:
The accelerating force acting on all falling objects is gravity and it would make them all accelerate at the same rate if it wasn't for air resistance.

On the Moon, where there's no air the hammer and feather hit the ground together, whereas on Earth, the air resistance causes things to fall at different speeds (terminal velocity depends on an object's drag vs weight).

question: With reference to terminal velocity, describe why parachutes are important for skydivers
answer:
If the skydiver has no parachute, he has a small area and force equal to his weight pulling him down. But when the parachute is open there's more air resistance and the same force pulling him down.

His terminal velocity decreases significantly, so he can land safely.

question: State the first law of motion
answer:
Balanced forces mean no change in velocity

If the forces on an object are balanced, it will carry on moving at the same velocity (this includes staying still).

question: Objects need a constant overall force to keep moving - true or false?
answer:
FALSE

To keep going at a steady speed there needs to be zero resultant force (forces would be balanced).

question: State Newton's second law of motion
answer:
If there is an unbalanced force, the object will accelerate in that direction

(Note: you get a steady speed from balanced forces but acceleration from an overall force)

question: State the formula for the second law of motion
answer:
F = ma

(F = resultant force, m = mass, a = acceleration)

question: What is Newton's third law of motion?
answer: If object A exerts a force on object B, then object B exerts the exact opposite force on object A

question: What's the difference between a vector and scalar quantity?
answer:
Vector quantities have a size and direction

Scalar quantities only have a size (no direction)

question: Give examples of vector quantities
answer:
• Force
• Velocity
• Displacemet
• Acceleration
• Momentum

question: List some scalar quantities
answer:
• Mass
• Temperature
• Time
• Length
